element.name: LipidProfile
element.formal: The findings and interpretation of a general lipd lab profile.
element.comments: In this profile, mustSupport means that authoring systems must include the ability to report these elements, and processing systems must cater for them by either displaying them to the user or considering them appropriately in decision support systems.
element.requirements: To support reporting for any diagnostic report into a clinical data repository.

element.formal: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.formal: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the url. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comments: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

element.short: When the resource version last changed
element.formal: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comments: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.formal: A list of profiles that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to Profile.url.
element.comments: It is up to the server and/or other infrastruture of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over tiem.

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.formal: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comments: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.formal: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comments: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.formal: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: LOINC Code for Lipid Panel with LDL
element.formal: LOINC Code for Lipid Panel with LDL.
element.comments: LOINC code includes "direct" LDL - does this mean LDL derived by measuring VLDL by ultracentrifugation? This panel includes both measured and calculated LDL.

coding.display: Lipid panel with direct LDL - Serum or Plasma

mapping.map: OBR-4-Universal Service ID (V2 doesn't provide an easy way to indicate both the ordered test and the performed panel)
OBR-4-Universal Service ID (V2 doesn't provide an easy way to indicate both the ordered test and the performed panel)

element.formal: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications need to take appropriate action if a report is withdrawn.
element.requirements: Diagnostic services routinely issue provisional/incomplete reports, and sometimes withdraw previously released reports.

binding.name: DiagnosticReportStatus
binding.description: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole

mapping.map:
statusCode

Note: final and amended are distinguished by whether observation is the subject of a ControlAct event of type "revise"

statusCode

Note: final and amended are distinguished by whether observation is the subject of a ControlAct event of type "revise"

element.formal: The date and/or time that this version of the report was released from the source diagnostic service.
element.comments: May be different from the update time of the resource itself, because that is the status of the record (potentially a secondary copy), not the actual release time of the report .
element.requirements: Clinicians need to be able to check the date that the report was released.

element.short: The subject of the report, usually, but not always, the patient
element.formal: The subject of the report. Usually, but not always, this is a patient. However diagnostic services also perform analyses on specimens collected from a variety of other sources.

mapping.map: PID-3-Patient ID List (no V2 mapping for Group or Device)
PID-3-Patient ID List (no V2 mapping for Group or Device)

element.formal: The diagnostic service that is responsible for issuing the report.
element.comments: This is not necessarily the source of the atomic data items - it is the entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.
element.requirements: Need to know whom to contact if there are queries about the results. Also may need to track the source of reports for secondary data analysis.

element.short: Id for external references to this report
element.formal: The local ID assigned to the report by the order filler, usually by the Information System of the diagnostic service provider.
element.requirements: Need to know what identifier to use when making queries about this report from the source laboratory, and for linking to the report outside FHIR context.

mapping.map: OBR-51-Observation Group ID (todo: check semantic intent of OBR-51 with OOWG)
OBR-51-Observation Group ID (todo: check semantic intent of OBR-51 with OOWG)

element.formal: Details concerning a test requested.
element.comments: Note: Usually there is one test request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single test result resource. Note that there are also cases where one request leads to multiple reports.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track completion of requests based on reports issued and also to report what diagnostic tests were requested (not always the same as what is delivered).

element.formal: The section of the diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, hematology, MRI.
element.requirements: Help clinicians filter/find the reports they are looking for.

element.formal: The time or time-period the observed values are related to. This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection(s), but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
element.comments: If the diagnostic procedure was performed on the patient, this is the time it was performed. If there are specimens, the diagnostically relevant time can be derived from the specimen collection times, but the specimen information is not always available, and the exact relationship between the specimens and the diagnostically relevant time is not always automatic.
element.requirements: Need to know where in the patient history to file/present this report.

element.short: Specimens this report is based on
element.formal: Details about the specimens on which this diagnostic report is based.
element.comments: If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data may be redundant. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per Observation or group.
element.requirements: Need to be able to report information about the collected specimens on which the report is based.

element.short: Observations - simple, or complex nested groups
element.formal: Observations that are part of this diagnostic report. Observations can be simple name/value pairs (e.g. "atomic" results), or they can be grouping observations that include references to other members of the group (e.g. "panels").
element.requirements: Need to be able to individual results, or report groups of results, where the result grouping is arbitrary, but meaningful. This structure is recursive - observations can contain observations.

element.name: Cholesterol
element.formal: Reference to Cholesterol Result.
element.requirements: Need to be able to individual results, or report groups of results, where the result grouping is arbitrary, but meaningful. This structure is recursive - observations can contain observations.

element.name: Triglyceride
element.formal: Group of elements for Triglyceride result.
element.requirements: Need to be able to individual results, or report groups of results, where the result grouping is arbitrary, but meaningful. This structure is recursive - observations can contain observations.

element.name: HDL Cholesterol
element.formal: Group of elements for HDL Cholesterol result.
element.requirements: Need to be able to individual results, or report groups of results, where the result grouping is arbitrary, but meaningful. This structure is recursive - observations can contain observations.

element.name: LDL Cholesterol
element.formal: LDL Cholesterol result, if reported.
element.requirements: Need to be able to individual results, or report groups of results, where the result grouping is arbitrary, but meaningful. This structure is recursive - observations can contain observations.

element.short: Reference to full details of imaging associated with the diagnostic report
element.formal: One or more links to full details of any imaging performed during the diagnostic investigation. Typically, this is imaging performed by DICOM enabled modalities, but this is not required. A fully enabled PACS viewer can use this information to provide views of the source images.
element.comments: ImagingStudy and image are somewhat overlapping - typically, an image in the image list will also be found in the imaging study resource. However the imaging study and image lists cater to different types of displays for different types of purposes. Neither, either, or both may be provided.

element.short: Key images associated with this report
element.formal: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and may be directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).
element.requirements: Many diagnostic services include images in the report as part of their service.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. element.formal: A comment about the image. Typically, this is used to provide an explanation for why the image is included, or to draw the viewer's attention to important features.
element.comments: The comment should be displayed with the image. It would be common for the report to include additional discussion of the image contents in other sections such as the conclusion.
element.requirements: The provider of the report should make a comment about each image included in the report.

element.formal: Reference to the image source.
May include diagnosis or suggestions for follow up testing.
element.comments: It's not unusual for the lab to make some kind of interpretative comment on the set of results.
element.requirements: Need to be able to provide a conclusion that is not lost amongst the basic result data.

element.short: No codes for a lipid panel
element.formal: No codes for a lipid panel.
element.comments: Not used in this context.

binding.name: AdjunctDiagnosis
binding.description: Diagnoses codes provided as adjuncts to the report

element.formal: Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they SHALL be semantically equivalent.
element.comments: Application/pdf is recommended as the most reliable and interoperable in this context.
element.requirements: Gives Laboratory the ability to provide its own fully formatted report for clinical fidelity.
